comments.text:  format_esc produces an ANSI escape code, for selecting the graphics rendition of the following
 text. Each of the attributes that can be passed in `code`, separated by `;`, will be in effect,
 until the terminal encounters another SGR ANSI escape code. For more details about the different
 codes, and their meaning, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code#SGR_(Select_Graphic_Rendition)_parameters
 format returns ANSI escape coded `msg` formatted with a preceding
 `open` and a succeeding `close`.
 For instance, `format('hi', '9', '29')` returns `'\x1b[9mhi\x1b[29m'`,
 or 'hi' with strikethrough, where `'\x1b[9m'` represents
 crossed out/strikethrough text and `'\x1b[29m'` turns off strikethrough.

contents.content: fn format(msg string, open string, close string) string
contents.name: format

comments.text:  format_rgb returns ANSI escape coded `msg` formatted with a preceding
 `open`, a succeeding `close` and the provided RGB colors `r`, `g`, and `b`.

contents.content: fn format_rgb(r int, g int, b int, msg string, open string, close string) string
contents.name: format_rgb

comments.text:  rbg returns the `msg` with the foreground in the specified RGB color
 For example, `rgb(0, 255, 0, 'hi')` returns the `'hi'` string in
 lime color.

contents.content: fn rgb(r int, g int, b int, msg string) string
contents.name: rgb

comments.text:  bg_rgb returns the `msg` with the background in the specified RGB color.
 For example, `bg_rgb(255, 0, 0, 'hi')` returns the text `'hi'` in
 red color.

contents.content: fn bg_rgb(r int, g int, b int, msg string) string
contents.name: bg_rgb

comments.text:  hex returns the `msg` with the foreground in the specified `hex` color
 For example, `rgb(255, 'hi')` returns the `'hi'` string in
 blue color, which is `(0, 0, 255)` in RGB.

contents.content: fn hex(hex int, msg string) string
contents.name: hex

comments.text:  hex returns the `msg` with the background in the specified `hex` color
 For example, `bg_rgb(255, 'hi')` returns the `'hi'` string in
 a background of blue color, which is `(0, 0, 255)` in RGB.

contents.content: fn bg_hex(hex int, msg string) string
contents.name: bg_hex

comments.text:  reset resets all formatting for `msg`.
 bold returns the given `msg` in bold.
 dim returns the dimmed `msg`.
 italic returns the given `msg` in italic.
 underline returns the underlined `msg`.
 slow_blink will surround the `msg` with ANSI escape codes for blinking (less than 150 times per minute).
 rapid_blink will surround the `msg` with ANSI escape codes for blinking (over 150 times per minute).
 Note that unlike slow_blink, this is not very widely supported.
 inverse inverses the given `msg`.
 hidden hides the given `msg`.
 strikethrough returns the given `msg` in strikethrough.
 black formats the `msg` in black.
 red formats the `msg` in red.
 green formats the `msg` in green.
 yellow formats the `msg` in yellow.
 blue formats the `msg` in blue.
 magenta formats the `msg` in magenta.
 cyan formats the `msg` in cyan.
 white formats the `msg` in white.
 bg_black formats the `msg` in black background.
 bg_red formats the `msg` in red background.
 bg_green formats the `msg` in green background.
 bg_yellow formats the `msg` in yellow background.
 bg_blue formats the `msg` in blue background.
 bg_magenta formats the `msg` in magenta background.
 bg_cyan formats the `msg` in cyan background.
 bg_white formats the `msg` in white background.
 gray formats the `msg` in gray (equivalent to `bright_black`).
 bright_black formats the `msg` in bright black.
 bright_red formats the `msg` in bright red.
 bright_green formats the `msg` in bright green.
 bright_yellow formats the `msg` in bright yellow.
 bright_blue formats the `msg` in bright blue.
 bright_magenta formats the `msg` in bright magenta.
 bright_cyan formats the `msg` in bright cyan.
 bright_white formats the `msg` in bright white.
 bright_bg_black formats the `msg` in bright black background.
 bright_bg_red formats the `msg` in bright red background.
 bright_bg_green formats the `msg` in bright green background.
 bright_bg_yellow formats the `msg` in bright yellow background.
 bright_bg_blue formats the `msg` in bright blue background.
 bright_bg_magenta formats the `msg` in bright magenta background.
 bright_bg_cyan formats the `msg` in bright cyan background.
 bright_bg_white formats the `msg` in bright white background.
 highlight_command highlights the command with an on-brand background
 to make CLI commands immediately recognizable.
 Sources for ANSI Control Sequences
 https://github.com/RajeshPatkarInstitute/Panim
 https://www.gnu.org/software/screen/manual/html_node/Control-Sequences.html
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code
 Support for Windows
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI.SYS
 #include <windows.h>
 C.SetConsoleMode(C.ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_INPUT)
 Setting cursor to the given position
 x is the x coordinate
 y is the y coordinate
 n is number of cells
 direction: A is up / North
 direction: B is down / South
 direction: C is forward / East
 direction: D is backward / West
 cursor_up moves the cursor up `n` lines.
 cursor_down moves the cursor down `n` lines.
 cursor_forward moves the cursor forward `n` character positions.
 cursor_back moves the cursor back `n` characters.
 erase_display erases display characters based on the given parameter, `t`.
 `t` can be of the following values in string:
 `0`: current cursor position to end of the terminal window.
 `1`: current cursor position to beginning of the terminal
 window.
 `2`: clears the entire terminal window.
 `3`: clears the entire terminal window and also deletes the scrollback buffer.
 erase_to_end erases from the cursor to the end of the terminal window.
 erase_tobeg erases from the cursor to the beginning of the terminal window.
 erase_clear clears the entire terminal window and returns the cursor to the
 top left corner.
 erase_del_clear erases saved lines.
 erase_line erases the current line based on the given parameter, `t`.
 `t` can be of the following values in string:
 `0`: current cursor position to the end of the line.
 `1`: current cursor position to the beginning of the line.
 `2`: clears the entire line.
 Note: Cursor position does not change.
 erase_line_toend erases from the cursor position to the end of the line.
 erase_line_tobeg erases from the start of the line to the cursor
 position.
 erase_line_clear erases the entire line.
 show_cursor makes the cursor appear if it was not visible.
 Will make cursor invisible
 clear_previous_line - useful for progressbars.
 It moves the cursor to start of line, then 1 line above,
 then erases the line. In effect the next println will overwrite
 the previous content.
 Coord - used by term.get_cursor_position and term.set_cursor_position

contents.name: Coord

comments.text:  can_show_color_on_stdout returns true if colors are allowed in stdout;
 returns false otherwise.
 can_show_color_on_stderr returns true if colors are allowed in stderr;
 returns false otherwise.
 failed returns a bold white on red version of the string `s`
 If colors are not allowed, returns the string `s`
 ok_message returns a colored string with green color.
 If colors are not allowed, returns a given string.
 fail_message returns a colored string with red color.
 If colors are not allowed, returns a given string.
 warn_message returns a colored string with yellow color.
 If colors are not allowed, returns a given string.
 colorize returns a colored string by running the specified `cfn` over
 the message `s`, only if colored stdout is supported by the terminal.
 Example: term.colorize(term.yellow, 'the message')

contents.content: fn colorize(cfn fn (string) string, s string) string
contents.name: colorize

comments.text:  ecolorize returns a colored string by running the specified `cfn` over
 the message `s`, only if colored stderr is supported by the terminal.
 Example: term.ecolorize(term.bright_red, 'the message')

contents.content: fn ecolorize(cfn fn (string) string, s string) string
contents.name: ecolorize

comments.text:  strip_ansi removes any ANSI sequences in the `text`
 h_divider returns a horizontal divider line with a dynamic width,
 that depends on the current terminal settings.
 If an empty string is passed in, print enough spaces to make a new line
 header_left returns a horizontal divider line with a title text on the left.
 e.g: term.header_left('TITLE', '=')

contents.content: fn header_left(text string, divider string) string
contents.name: header_left

comments.text:  header returns a horizontal divider line with a centered text in the middle.
 e.g: term.header('TEXT', '=')

contents.content: fn header(text string, divider string) string
contents.name: header
C.COORD

struct C.SMALL_RECT {
mut:
	Left   u16
	Top    u16
	Right  u16
	Bottom u16
}

struct C.CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO {
mut:
	dwSize              C.COORD
	dwCursorPosition    C.COORD
	wAttributes         u16
	srWindow            C.SMALL_RECT
	dwMaximumWindowSize C.COORD
}
contents.name: C.CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO
C.uChar
C.CHAR_INFO

comments.text:  get_terminal_size returns a number of columns and rows of terminal window.
 get_cursor_position returns a Coord containing the current cursor position
 set_terminal_title changes the terminal title
 set_tab_title changes the terminal *tab title*, for terminal emulators that do support several tabs
 clear clears current terminal screen.
 Implementation taken from https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/clearing-the-screen#example-2.
 utf8_getchar returns an utf8 rune from standard input
 utf8_len calculates the length of a utf8 rune to read, according to its first byte

contents.content:
struct C.termios {
mut:
	c_iflag int
	c_oflag int
	c_cflag int
	c_lflag int
	c_cc    [20]u8
}
contents.name: C.termios
